message: It's only a skeleton at the moment, and there's much to be written.
I'm finally starting to work on a project I've been wanting to write for a long time: python-guide.org
If anyone is interested in helping (or has any suggestions), fork the repo on github or send me an email <me@kennethreitz.com>
any idea how different opinions on some topic will be handled?
@vasil, there's plenty of room for both
Part of this project is attempting to establish those best practices too
I'm not sure I agree with you completely on the *single* recommended way thing
link: http://python-guide.org
The goal of the project is to be an excellent guide and resource for novice and expert python developers, teaching best practices and giving recommendations
github url: https://github.com/kennethreitz/python-guide
example, some people love macports for installing python versions and libraries while others despise it
@micrypt exactly
and presenting either as a best practice may not be the right thing to do
I think it's something that's missing in the Python community at the moment.
Example: I think there *should* be a single recommended way to install Python for purpose X.
@Vasil Through the issue tracker I'd expect. :)
@Vasil imo, anyone who *likes* macports is simply wrong. :)
And if there isn't a single recommended way, then one needs to be created.
Requiring a single recommended way on some of the topics is asking for endless flamewars
@vasil, certainly not for everything. But for installation? yes.
@Vasil how popular it is and why, what people use it for, installation, examples, notes, etc
my goal will be for it to have notes on everything
i'd like for it to be 10x's bigger than that
but i can't do it all myself :)
there's a pretty broad outline in place already: http://docs.python-guide.org/en/latest/index.html
of course

Say I'd like to jump in on some of the practical sections, say web development. What should a section for each of those frameworks include? A description with links, notes on installing, code samples, best practices?
great resources
it would be nice if it has notes on alternative implementations
sections
also, encourage novices to post requests for a topic by linking to the issue tracker directly
@Vasil, absolutely.
great idea
Cool. As someone who's just set about learning Python, this kind of resource would be invaluable. I'll definitely keep my eye on it. And if you want beginner feedback, just give me a shout :)
re: "macports/etc" From zen of python: There should be one-- and preferably only one --obvious way to do it.
@justinlilly ★ x100
I too would be happy to give feedback from a novice perspective
